docs.lead_paragraph: The President of Colombia, Belisario Betancur, has asked President Reagan to halt deportation proceedings against a Latin American scholar at the University of Maryland, the White House said today. In addition, people close to the scholar, Angel Rama, said that, after Mr. Betancur's request, immigration officials indicated for the first time a willingness to tell Mr. Rama of the charges against him. The deputy White House press secretary, Larry Speakes, said Mr. Betancur had ''raised the name'' of Mr. Rama during Mr. Reagan's recent trip to Central America and South America.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gottfried Defeats Borg, 6-1, 6-3 NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP) - Brian Gottfried slowed the comeback of Bjorn Borg tonight with a 6-1, 6-3 victory over the Swede that moved Gottfried into the semifinals of the $300,000 Nastase-Hamptons Invitational tennis tournament. Gottfried, who eliminated second-seeded Guillermo Vilas in the second round Thursday night, will meet Heinz Gunthardt of Switzerland, a 6-3, 3-6, 6-4 quarterfinal winner over Jimmy Arias, in one of Saturday's semifinals at the Hamptons Country Club. Brian Teacher defeated Vince Van Patten, 6-3, 6-1, and top-seeded Jimmy Connors beat Shlomo Glickstein of Israel, 6-2, 6-3, to set up a meeting in the other semifinal.

docs.lead_paragraph: A New Melting Pot: The City in the 80's Last of nine articles that have appeared periodically since Sept. 27. By DENA KLEIMAN They live across the hall from one another - two couples who could not have less in common. One grew up in Brooklyn, the other on the outskirts of Saigon. And yet they have had a powerful impact on each other's lives by sharing what they know best. Miriam and Bernard Roiss used to pride themselves on their recipes for Hungarian goulash and kidney pie. Now they stock rice wrappers in their refrigerator and eat most of their meals with chopsticks.

docs.lead_paragraph: He was a major in the Argentine army, and he was sitting bare chested and angry on the beach at the resort town of Mar del Plata. He and his military colleagues, he complained, were being accused abroad of being torturers and assassins, and accused at home of being bunglers. People had forgotten, he said. They had forgotten that the nation was in peril in March 1976 when the armed forces overthrew President Isabel Martinez de Peron. Political terrorists were running amok, and the economy was in havoc. ''We did what we had to do,'' he said. The costs were high. Many thousands on both sides were killed, including more than 6,000 who were reportedly ''disappeared'' into the hands of state security forces. ''But every war,'' he said, ''has its casualties and missing.''

byline.original: By Edward Schumacher; Edward Schumacher is chief of The New York Time's bureau in Buenos Aires

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years after he began serving a Federal prison term for bank fraud, Michele Sindona is enmeshed in international investigations involving multimillion-dollar financial swindles, a mysterious right-wing political organization, murder and the underworld. Mr. Sindona once headed a $500 million financial empire. He was a financial adviser to the Vatican and sped to the world's financial capitals in a private jet. Now, at a Federal prison in Otisville, N.Y., he is a gaunt, grayhaired figure, clothed in a drab blue-denim uniform and sneakers. He snacks on apple juice with pretzels and broods about his financial ruin, his 25-year prison sentence in the United States and criminal charges pending against him in his native Italy.

headline.main: SINDONA, IN U.S. PRISON, STAYS ENMESHED IN GLOBAL INQUIRIES
